revision.text:
{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 2015 Washington, D.C., mass killing | location = [[Woodley Park]], [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | target = Savopoulos family | coordinates = | date = May 13–14, 2015 | time = | type = Mass killing, arson | timezone = | fatalities = 4 | injuries = | susperp = Daron Dylon Wint<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wjla.com/news/local/d-c-mansion-murders-not-random-police-chief-says-suspect-remains-at-large-114135|title=Ex-con Daron Wint appears in court, had help in D.C. quadruple slayings, authorities say|work=[[WJLA-TV]]|date=May 21, 2015|accessdate=December 30, 2015|first=Brianne|last=Carter|first2=Sam|last2=Ford|first3=Tom|last3=Roussey|first4=Jennifer|last4=Donelan}}</ref> and unknown accomplices | weapons = Knife, blunt object, fire by arson<ref name=murder>{{cite news|first1=Pamela|last1=Brown|first2=Joe|last2=Johns|first3=Alexandra|last3=Jaffe|first4=Kevin|last4=Conlon|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/21/us/dc-house-fire-money-motive/index.html|title=Source: Suspect in DC quadruple homicide, arson arrested|work=[[CNN]]|date=May 22, 2015|accessdate=May 22, 2015}}</ref> }}
On May 14, 2015, three members of the Savopoulos family—Savvas, Amy, and their son Philip—as well as their housekeeper, Veralicia Figueroa, were killed at the Savopoulos home in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name=murder/><ref name=murderer>{{cite news|last1=Jouvenal|first1=Justin|last2=Zapotosky|first2=Matt|last3=Morse|first3=Dan|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/probe-continues-into-mysterious-deaths-of-four-in-burning-dc-home/2015/05/15/8936d0aa-fb24-11e4-9ef4-1bb7ce3b3fb7_story.html|title=Four found in D.C. fire were slain, police say|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 15, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref> The victims were held hostage for 19 hours, starting on May 13. Ten-year-old Philip was tortured in order to coerce $40,000 in cash from the family.<ref name=cash>{{cite news|last=Leshan|first=Bruce|url=http://www.wusa9.com/story/news/local/2015/05/20/savopoulis-10-year-old-boy-tortured-before-murders-and-fire-in-dc/27643991/|title=$40K delivered to home, boy tortured before DC murders, fire|work=[[WUSA (TV)]]|date=May 20, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref> The perpetrator(s) restrained them with [[duct tape]] before killing them, then set the house on fire.<ref name=murderer/> They all sustained [[blunt force trauma]], and Philip was also stabbed. On October 25, 2018 the defendant Daron Wint, a welder fired from a company owned by Savvas Savopoulos was found guilty of 20 counts of kidnapping, extortion and murder. <ref name="foundguilty">{{cite news|title=DC Mansion Murders defendant found guilty on all counts|url=https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/local/dc-mansion-murders-defendant-found-guilty-on-all-counts/65-608074660?ref=exit-recirc|accessdate=October 25, 2018|work=[[WUSA (TV)]]|date=October 25, 2018 |location=Washington, DC}}</ref>
==Robbery and murder== The perpetrators stole $40,000 in cash from the family after an assistant, Jordan Wallace, delivered it to the house.<ref name=cash/> They also stole the family's blue [[Porsche 911|Porsche]],<ref name=cash/> which was later found burned in a church parking lot in Maryland.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wtop.com/dc/2015/05/report-d-c-family-held-killed-house-torched/|title=Report: D.C. family was held before being killed, house torched|work=[[WTOP-FM]]|date=May 19, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref>
On May 14, 2015, the Savopoulos house in [[Northwest Washington, D.C.|Northwest Washington]] was spotted ablaze and firefighters were called. They discovered the three bodies of the Savopoulos family and their housekeeper.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marraco|first1=Marina|last2=Limon|first2=Alexandra|url=http://www.myfoxdc.com/story/29066982/four-dead-fire|title=3 adults, 1 child found dead at suspicious NW DC house fire|work=[[WTTG]]|date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref> The police determined the fire was intentionally set, and the victims had blunt-force and stab wounds, leading them to label the deaths homicides.<ref name=murderer/>
==Victims== The Savopouloses were a prominent, upper-class family in the [[Woodley Park]] neighborhood of Northwest Washington. Savvas Savopoulos was the CEO and president of American Iron Works, a construction company that played a role in building the [[Verizon Center]].<ref name=murderer/>
The slain victims are:
* Savvas Phillip Savopoulos, age 46, a prominent area businessman * Amy Clare Savopoulos (''née'' Martin), age 47, Savvas's wife * Philip Savvas Savopoulos, age 10, their son * Veralicia Figueroa, age 57, their housekeeper
Two teenage daughters, Abigail and Katerina Savopoulos, were not present at the scene when the four were killed.<ref name="Daughters">{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Wills|title=Surviving daughter of DC mansion murder posts moving photos in tribute to her slain parents and brother as the trial is delayed|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3250990/Surviving-daughter-DC-mansion-murders-posts-tributes-parents-brother-trial-delayed-December.html|work=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=27 September 2015}}</ref>
== Suspect == '''Daron Dylon Wint''' (born November 27, 1980) was identified by police as the prime suspect in the case. He was found by matching his DNA to that found on the crust of a [[Domino's Pizza|Domino's]] pizza delivered to the house on May 13, while the family was apparently captive.<ref name=pizza>{{cite news|last1=Phillip|first1=Abby|last2=Alexander|first2=Keith L.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2015/05/21/how-a-dominos-pizza-crust-led-police-to-a-suspect-in-the-d-c-mansion-murders/|title=How a Domino's pizza crust led police to a suspect in mysterious D.C. slayings|work=The Washington Post|date=May 21, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref> He was a certified welder who formerly worked at American Iron Works, leading police to believe the murders weren't random.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hermann|first1=Peter|last2=Bui|first2=Lynh|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/police-search-for-suspect-in-savopoulos-slayings/2015/05/21/3d707c0c-ffa7-11e4-833c-a2de05b6b2a4_story.html|title=Suspect in quadruple killings worked for victims’ family business, police say|work=The Washington Post|date=May 21, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref>
Wint is originally from [[Guyana]] and immigrated to the U.S. in 2000. He was a [[United States Marine Corps]] recruit but was discharged before his training was complete for medical reasons. He had a long [[rap sheet]] of criminal charges; he was convicted in 2009 of second-degree assault in Maryland and sentenced to 30 days in jail, and also pleaded guilty to the crime of malicious destruction of property in 2010 as part of a plea deal, in which a second charge, burglary, was dropped.<ref name=arrest>{{cite news|last1=Nuckols|first1=Ben|title=Suspect in killings of wealthy DC family arrested|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/4c2cb1e7a0e14dbbad799c78e9b43957/suspect-killings-wealthy-dc-family-arrested|accessdate=May 22, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=May 22, 2015}}</ref> He has also been charged in the past with theft, assault, a sexual offense,<ref name=murder /> and weapons possession.<ref name=arrest/>
After Wint's DNA was matched, a warrant was issued for his arrest on a charge of [[first-degree murder]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wjla.com/articles/2015/05/arrest-warrant-issued-for-suspect-in-quadruple-murder-on-may-14-in-northwest-d-c--114123.html|title=Suspect ID'd in quadruple murder in Northwest D.C.|work=WJLA-TV|date=May 20, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref> Wint was found and arrested on May 21, 2015, in northeast Washington, a week after the murders,<ref name=arrest/> and was subsequently charged with first-degree murder.<ref name=prosecution>{{cite news|last1=Botelho|first1=Greg|last2=Mallonee|first2=Mary Kay|last3=Payne|first3=Ed|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/22/us/washington-mansion-fire-slayings/index.html|title=Prosecutors: Suspect in Washington family's killings did not act alone|work=CNN|date=May 22, 2015|accessdate=May 22, 2015}}</ref>
Prosecutors believe Wint had help killing the victims and did not act alone.<ref name=prosecution/> Wint is the only person charged in the deaths.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/savopoulos-family-thanks-law-enforcement-after-arrest-in-slayings/2015/05/22/4b5b488a-0077-11e5-8b6c-0dcce21e223d_story.html|title=Suspect in 4 gruesome D.C. killings might not have acted alone, police say|first=Peter|last=Hermann|date=May 22, 2015|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=December 30, 2015}}</ref>
== Reactions == Attorney [[Robin Ficker]] said that Wint did not seem violent when he defended him in earlier cases. "My impression of him — I remember him rather well — is that he wouldn't hurt a fly. He's a very nice person," Ficker said.<ref name=arrest/> He then characterized Wint as "kind and gentle" and added that authorities have arrested "the wrong guy" in the Savopoulos case, claiming, "They've made a big mistake here."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Botelho|first1=Greg|title=Who is DC murder suspect Darron Dellon Dennis Wint ?|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/22/us/washington-murder-suspect-wint/|accessdate=May 23, 2015|work=CNN|date=May 22, 2015}}</ref> Ficker also said that Wint's family had told him "that he doesn't like pizza and never eats pizza", referring to the matching of Wint's DNA to that found on a pizza crust at the crime scene.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Iannelli|first1=Nick|title=Daron Wint's family doesn't believe he is guilty of D.C. murder, arson|url=http://wtop.com/dc/2015/05/daron-wints-family-doesnt-believe-he-is-guilty-of-d-c-murder-arson/|accessdate=June 2, 2015|work=WTOP-FM|date=May 26, 2015}}</ref>
The father of Wint says his son should "suffer the consequences" if found guilty.<ref name="FatherSuspect">{{cite news|last1=Thornhill|first1=Ted|last2=Robinson|first2=Wills|title=Father of DC mansion quadruple murder suspect says his son should 'suffer the consequences' for 'heartless' crime if found guilty|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3100479/Father-quadruple-murder-suspect-DC-mansion-fire-says-son-Daron-Wint-suffer-consequences-heartless-crime-guilty.html|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=The Daily Mail|date=27 May 2015}}</ref>
After almost two years, the five-bedroom, six-bathroom house was demolished. Located in the tony neighborhood near the National Cathedral, the property was once valued at $4.5 million but sold months after the killings for just $3 million.<ref name="Demolition">{{cite news|last1=Iacone|first1=Amanda|last2=Cloherty|first2=Megan|title=Demolition begins at posh DC home where 4 were killed|url=https://wtop.com/dc/2017/04/13547941/slide/1/|work=WTOP-FM|date=21 April 2017}}</ref>
The other housekeeper, Nelly Gutierrez, who worked for the Savopoulos family for nearly two decades and was working elsewhere on the day of the murders, spoke out two years afterwards.<ref name="OtherHousekeeper">{{cite news|title=Housekeeper, who narrowly escaped with her life, speaks out on second anniversary of DC mansion murders and reveals wife of wealthy CEO was 'distracted' in the weeks before she was killed|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5050655/Housekeeper-says-victim-DC-mansion-murders-stressed.html|work=The Daily Mail|date=November 4, 2017}}</ref>
== Trial == The trial date for Daron Wint was set on February 3, 2017 to begin September 4, 2018.<ref name="TrialSet">{{cite news|title=Trial Set in DC Mansion Murders Case|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Trial-Date-Could-Be-Set-in-DC-Mansion-Murders-Case-412658073.html|accessdate=November 5, 2017|work=[[WRC-TV]]|date=February 3, 2017|location=Washington, DC}}</ref> The trial began with opening statements on September 11, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=Opening statements in trial of Daron Wint, man accused in Savopoulos DC Mansion Murders case |url=http://www.fox5dc.com/news/local-news/opening-statements-in-trial-of-daron-wint-man-accused-in-savopoulos-dc-mansion-murders-case |accessdate=September 12, 2018 |work=WTTG |date=September 11, 2018}}</ref> On October 25, 2018 the defendant was found guilty of 20 counts of kidnapping, extortion and murder. <ref name="foundguilty"/>
== See also == * [[Capital punishment in the District of Columbia]] * [[Cheshire, Connecticut, home invasion murders]] * [[Crime in Washington, D.C.]]

(Wesley Johnson) |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Wesley Johnson |alias = 2Play, Wesley J, Special T |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1977|7|22}} |death_date = |origin = London, England |genre = [[Dancehall]], [[reggae]], [[contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], [[UK garage]] |occupation = Musician, record producer, songwriter, rapper |years_active = 1997–present |associated_acts = [[Raghav]], Jucxi D, [[Maxi Priest]], [[Moni]], [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules |website = }} {{about|the British musician|the article about a multiplayer game of two players|Two-player game|the article about a multiplayer video game|Two-player video game}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} '''Wesley Johnson''' (born 1977), known by his stage name '''2Play''',Graham Betts Complete UK Hit Albums 1956-2005 2005 - Page 330 "Raghav Mathur (bom 1983) who was educated at ... He won the 2004 MOBO Award for Best Collaboration with 2Play and Jucxi for So Confused." is a British musician, record producer, and former [[mixed martial artist]]. ==Music career== 2Play is a [[Music of Black Origin Awards|MOBO]] Award–winning record producer and musician.{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/performer/2play|title=2play - Music Charts|publisher=}} He is best known for songs with the Canadian-Indian singer [[Raghav]], as well as collaborations with a number of artists including Jucxi D, [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules and Moni. 2Play first entered the music scene in 1997 as a [[UK garage]] producer under the alias Special T.{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/291524-Special-T|title=Special T|publisher=}} He has had two UK [[Top 40|Top 10]] [[hit single]]s: "So Confused" (featuring Raghav and Jucxi) and "It Can't Be Right" (featuring Raghav and Naila Boss).{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 571}} A [[cover version|cover]] of [[Kevin Lyttle]]'s "[[Turn Me On (Kevin Lyttle song)|Turn Me On]]" featuring Raghav and Jucxi appeared as a B-side to the single "So Confused". In 2005, "So Confused" also won "Best Single" at the [[UK Asian Music Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wass-up.com/ukama2005.php |title=Artists unite to celebrate British Asian Music |accessdate=24 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110150402/http://wass-up.com/ukama2005.php |archivedate=10 January 2011 }} He has produced cover versions of such songs as [[George Michael]]'s "[[Careless Whisper]]" (featuring Thomas Jules and Jucxi D) and [[Maxi Priest]]'s "[[Close to You (Maxi Priest song)|Close to You]]" (featuring Moni). ===Discography=== ====Singles==== {|class="wikitable" |- !rowspan="2"| Year !rowspan="2"| Single !| Chart positions !rowspan="2"| Album |- !width="30"|[[UK Singles Chart]] |- || 2003 |"So Confused" featuring [[Raghav]] and Jucxi | style="text-align:center;"| 6 |rowspan="2"| [[Storyteller (Raghav album)|Raghav album ''Storyteller'']] |- || 2004 |"It Can't Be Right" featuring [[Raghav]] and [[Naila Boss]] | style="text-align:center;"| 8 |- || 2005 |"[[Careless Whisper]]" featuring Thomas Jules and Jucxi D | style="text-align:center;"| 29 | |- || 2007 |"[[Close to You (Maxi Priest song)|Close to You]]" featuring Moni | style="text-align:center;"| – | |- || 2009 |"That's What the Girls Like" featuring [[Maxi Priest]], Moni and Jucxi D | style="text-align:center;"| – | |} ==Mixed martial arts== {{Infobox martial artist | name = Wesley Johnson | other_names = | image = | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|7|22|df=y}} | birth_place = London, England | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = English | height = | weight = | weight_class = [[Lightweight (MMA)|Lightweight]] | reach = | style = [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]], [[Karate]] | stance = | fighting_out_of = London, England | team = | rank = ''[[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu ranking system#Brown belt|brown belt]] in [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]]''

'''Abu Hafsa Yazid''' ({{lang-ar|ابو حفصة يزيد |translit=Abū Ḥafṣah Yazīd}}) was a [[mawla]], or servant, of the Umayyad Caliph [[Marwan I|Marwan ibn al-Hakkam]] (''r''. 684–685).<ref name=Khallikan>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eeE80B81GfgC&pg=PA343 |title=Ibn Khallikan's Biographical Dictionary |volume=3 |author=Ibn Khallikan |publisher=Oriental Translation Fund of Great Britain and Ireland |year=1868 |pages=343–347 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref> Yazid's full name is not known; ''Abu Hafsa'' means "father of Hafsa" (see [[Arabic name]]).
Marwan freed Yazid and assigned him posts including taxation in [[Medina]]. He married the daughter of the [[amir]] of [[al-Yamama]], and among their descendants were several prominent [[poet]]s of the early Islamic period, including [[Marwan ibn Abi Hafsa]] and [[Marwan ibn Abi al-Janub]].<ref name=Bosworth>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tPsUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA625 |title=The Encyclopedia of Islam |volume=6 |series=Fascicules 107-108 |first=Clifford Edmund |last=Bosworth |publisher=Brill Archive |year=1989 |isbn=90-04-09082-7 |page=625 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref><ref name=Meisami>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DbCFBX6b3eEC&pg=PA511 |title=Encyclopedia of Arabic Literature |volume=2 |first1=Julie Scott |last1=Meisami |first2=Paul |last2=Starkey |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=1998 |isbn=0-415-18572-6 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref>
Abu Hafsa Yazid's origins are unclear; he may have been either [[Persian people|Persian]] or [[Jews|Jewish]].<ref name=Bosworth/> He may have been taken prisoner as a youth in the capture of [[Istakhr]] in ca 650 CE, and later sold to the [[Caliph]]. He was freed on the day of the assassination of [[Uthman ibn Affan]]. Sources vary as to whether Abu Hafsa Yazid converted to [[Islam]] or retained his [[Judaism|Jewish faith]].<ref name=Khallikan/>
Abu Hafsa Yazid is sometimes described as court [[physician]] to the [[Caliph]] [[Umar I]] around the year 643 CE,<ref name=Jewish>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DL5tAAAAMAAJ |title=The Universal Jewish Encyclopedia |volume=8 |first=Isaac |last=Landman |editor=Simon Cohen |publisher=The Universal Jewish Encyclopedia, Inc |year=1942 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref> however this may be an error based on writings by later [[Arabian history|Arab historians]], as he is not called a physician in the earliest texts.<ref name=Siddiqi>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7C9rAAAAMAAJ |title=Studies in Arabic and Persian Medical Literature |first=Muḥammad Zubair |last=Siddiqi |publisher=Calcutta University |year=1959 |pages=6, 8 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref>

{{Infobox NFL player |name=Albert Haynesworth |image=Albert-Haynesworth-Feb-4-09-090204-N-9758L-030.jpg |image_size=187 |caption=Haynesworth in February 2009. |number=91, 92, 95 |position=[[Defensive tackle]] |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1981|6|17|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Hartsville, South Carolina]] |death_date= |death_place= |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 6 |weight_lbs = 350 |high_school = [[Hartsville High School|Hartsville (SC)]] |college=[[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] |draftyear=2002 |draftround=1 |draftpick=15 |pastteams= * [[Tennessee Titans]] ({{NFL Year|2002}}–{{NFL Year|2008}}) * [[Washington Redskins]] ({{NFL Year|2009}}–{{NFL Year|2010}}) * [[New England Patriots]] ({{NFL Year|2011}}) * [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] ({{NFL Year|2011}}) |highlights= * 2× [[Pro Bowl]] ([[2008 Pro Bowl|2007]], [[2009 Pro Bowl|2008]]) * 2× First-team [[All-Pro]] ([[2007 All-Pro Team|2007]], [[2008 All-Pro Team|2008]]) * ''[[Sporting News]]'' [[NFL Defensive Player of the Year]] (2008) * Second-team All-[[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] ([[2001 All-SEC football team|2001]]) * ''[[USA Today]]'' High School All-American ([[1998 USA Today All-USA high school football team|1998]]) |statlabel1=[[Tackle (football move)|Tackles]] |statvalue1=347 |statlabel2=[[Quarterback sack]]s |statvalue2=30.5 |statlabel3=[[Fumble|Forced fumbles]] |statvalue3=6 |nflnew=alberthaynesworth/2505019 }}
'''Albert George Haynesworth III''' (born June 17, 1981) is a former [[American football]] [[defensive tackle]] who played in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for ten seasons. He played [[college football]] at the [[University of Tennessee]]. Drafted by the [[Tennessee Titans]] in the first round (15th overall) of the [[2002 NFL Draft]], he spent his first seven NFL seasons with the Titans. An All-Pro selection in 2007 and 2008, and considered "the most dominant defensive tackle in the league" at that time,<ref name="TSNranking">{{cite news|title=Defensive tackle rankings: Nobody dominates like Haynesworth |url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/nfl/story/2009-05-21/defensive-tackle-rankings-nobody-dominates-haynesworth |work=[[The Sporting News]] |date=May 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d0eQRjI?url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/nfl/story/2009-05-21/defensive-tackle-rankings-nobody-dominates-haynesworth |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Haynesworth was a highly coveted [[free agent]] following the [[2008 NFL season|2008 season]]. He signed a seven-year, $100 million contract with the [[Washington Redskins]] in February 2009,<ref name="BattistaNYT">{{cite news |first=Judy |last=Battista |title=Paying Top Dollar, the Redskins Sign Haynesworth |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage-9A00E0DE1E3AF93BA15751C0A96F9C8B63.html\ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180726104119/https://archive.nytimes.com/query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage-9A00E0DE1E3AF93BA15751C0A96F9C8B63.html|archive-date=July 26, 2018 |work=New York Times |dead-url=yes |date=February 27, 2009 }}</ref> but played less than two full seasons with Washington. The Redskins' acquisition of Haynesworth has since been widely derided as the worst free agent signing in NFL history.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d81fe031a/article/easy-to-come-up-with-worst-freeagency-move-of-last-decade |title=Easy to come up with worst free-agency move of last decade |newspaper=NFL.com |date=May 17, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/nfl--worst-free-agent-signings-since--93--redskins--redskins-dominate-list-140917033.html |title=Worst free-agent signings since '93: Redskins, Raiders dominate list |newspaper=Yahoo! Sports |date=March 11, 2013 }}</ref>
==High school career== Haynesworth was born in [[Hartsville, South Carolina]]. He attended [[Hartsville High School]], and participated in [[high school football|football]], [[Track and field|track]], and [[shot put]].<ref name="HS">{{cite web|url=http://www.oocities.org/colosseum/midfield/4656/99vols.html.tmp |title=The Vol Signing Class of 1999 |publisher=Jumpmaster's Vols Page |accessdate=August 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cjoz0xi?url=http://www.oocities.org/colosseum/midfield/4656/99vols.html.tmp |archivedate=August 1, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Playing under head coach Lewis Lineberger, Haynesworth accounted for 150 tackles, 56 tackles for loss, six sacks, and six fumble recoveries as a junior; he followed that by tallying 110 tackles, 51 quarterback pressures, and six sacks as a senior in 1998.<ref name="HS" />
Following his senior season, Haynesworth was named a SuperPrep and Rivalnet All-American, and was also rated the fourth-best defensive lineman and the 14th-ranked overall player in the nation according to ESPN's Top 100, while National Recruiting Advisor rated him as the best defensive tackle in the country.<ref name="HS" /> He was a member of the [[Tennessee Volunteers football|University of Tennessee Volunteers]]' 1999 recruiting class.
==College career== As a student-athlete at the [[University of Tennessee]], Haynesworth was a three-year letterman for the [[Tennessee Volunteers football]] team under head coach [[Phillip Fulmer]]. He lined up at the right defensive tackle position next to [[John Henderson (defensive tackle)|John Henderson]]. He compiled 66 tackles, five sacks, 31 quarterback pressures, 20 tackles for a loss, and nine pass deflections during his collegiate career. He earned ''[[Sporting News]]'' Freshman All-American honors in 1999 and was named Second Team All-Southeastern Conference after his junior season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Five Vols Named to Associated Press All-SEC Teams|url=http://www.utsports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/120401aab.html|publisher=Tennessee Athletics|accessdate=August 21, 2011}}</ref>
==Professional career==
===2002 NFL Draft=== Considered "potentially a brutal run-stopper" by ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{Cite news |last=Freeman |first=Mike |date=March 31, 2002 |title=Panthers Could Ignore Talented Passers and Select Peppers Instead |newspaper=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/31/sports/pro-football-inside-nfl-panthers-could-ignore-talented-passers-select-peppers.html }}</ref> Haynesworth was selected by the Tennessee Titans in the first round with the 15th overall pick in the [[2002 NFL Draft]]. He was the fourth defensive tackle selected from a draft class considered to be loaded with talented defensive linemen.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Bell |first=Jarrett |date=April 18, 2002 |title=Big, agile defensive tackles at a premium for draft |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/nfl/2002draft/2002-04-16-cover.htm |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d0xTbar?url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/nfl/2002draft/2002-04-16-cover.htm |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> At Tennessee's Pro Day in 2002, when he was 20 years old, Haynesworth measured at 6-feet-6 and 317 pounds, ran a 4.82 40-yard dash, and had a 39-inch vertical jump and a 9-foot, 7-inch broad jump.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?document_id=0F2D74DE9A94FDF7 |title=Talent pool looks deep |first=Todd |last=Rosiak |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |date=April 11, 2002 }}</ref> He did not work out at the 2002 [[NFL Combine]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/news/2002/03/02/combine_saturday/ |title=No startling revelations in Combine's first two days |date=March 2, 2002 |last=Pauline |first=Tony |work=Sports Illustrated |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d15CRt2?url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/news/2002/03/02/combine_saturday/ |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
{{nfl predraft | height ft = 6 | height in = 5⅝ | weight = 317 | dash = 4.82 | ten split = | twenty split = | shuttle = | cone drill = | vertical = 39 | broad ft = 8 | broad in = 7 | bench = 39 | wonderlic = | arm span = | hand span = | note = All values from Tennessee Pro Day }}
===Tennessee Titans=== An incident foreshadowing future incidents with Haynesworth occurred at a Titans training camp in 2003, where Haynesworth kicked his former teammate, [[center (football)|center]] [[Justin Hartwig]], in the chest, then had to be restrained by other teammates.<ref>{{cite news|first=Mike |last=Cranston |title=Panthers' Hartwig fired up to face former team, Haynesworth |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2007-11-03-2157944303_x.htm |work=USA Today |date=November 3, 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d1HEXDV?url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2007-11-03-2157944303_x.htm |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
====Stomping incident==== On October 1, 2006, in the third quarter of a game against the [[2006 Dallas Cowboys season|Cowboys]], [[running back]] [[Julius Jones (American football player)|Julius Jones]] scored on a rushing play. Center [[Andre Gurode]] fell to the ground, and his helmet was removed by Haynesworth. Haynesworth tried to stomp on Gurode's head, but missed. A second stomp opened a severe wound on Gurode's forehead, narrowly missing his right eye. Referee [[Jerome Boger]] assessed Haynesworth a 15-yard unsportsmanlike conduct penalty, to which Haynesworth protested by taking off his helmet and throwing it into the turf; Haynesworth was then assessed an additional 15-yard penalty and ejected from the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3490689 |agency=Associated Press |title=Titans, Haynesworth fail to beat franchise deadline |date=July 15, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d1MpV9l?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3490689 |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Gurode later received 30 stitches just above and below his right eye. After the game, Titans head coach [[Jeff Fisher]] apologized on behalf of the Titans organization to Cowboys coach [[Bill Parcells]]. After the game, Haynesworth apologized,<ref>{{cite news|title=Haynesworth suspended for unprecedented five games |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2610577 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=October 3, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d1fapY4?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2610577 |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> saying "What I did out there was disgusting. It doesn't matter what the league does to me. The way I feel right now, you just can't describe it." Gurode later said that he would not seek criminal charges against Haynesworth. He continued to experience headaches and blurred vision as of October 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gurode accepts Haynesworth's apology |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2615573 |work=ESPN |date=October 6, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cykfH0m?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2615573 |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Video evidence of the play shows Haynesworth bend down towards Gurode prior to his helmet being off and prior to the stomps. Because the view is partially blocked by other players it is unclear whether Haynesworth manually removes the helmet. Therefore, most media outlets reported simply that Gurode's helmet was off. However, hometown columnist Mickey Spagnola<ref>[http://www.dallascowboys.com/news.cfm?editorialAuthor=1&id=0B7E6E03-CB7A-F0CF-054748FE721F0419 DallasCowboys.com – News<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201180429/http://www.dallascowboys.com/news.cfm?editorialAuthor=1&id=0B7E6E03-CB7A-F0CF-054748FE721F0419 |date=2006-12-01 }}</ref> of DallasCowboys.com argued that Haynesworth pulled off Gurode's helmet.
On October 2, 2006, Haynesworth was suspended for five games without pay by the NFL. The suspension was only the second multi-game suspension in NFL history for an on-the-field incident, more than twice as long as the previous longest suspension, given in [[1986 NFL season|1986]] by then-commissioner [[Pete Rozelle]] to [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay]] nose tackle [[Charles Martin (American football)|Charles Martin]].<ref name="BattistaNYT2006">{{cite news|first=Judy |last=Battista |title=Titan Player Suspended 5 Games for Kicks to Head |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/03/sports/football/03titans.html |work=New York Times |date=October 3, 2006 |accessdate=February 18, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cyqGNGP?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/03/sports/football/03titans.html |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Based on his 2006 base salary of $646,251, Haynesworth forfeited more than $190,000.<ref name="BattistaNYT2006" /> NFL Commissioner [[Roger Goodell]], who had been on the job a month, stated that there was "absolutely no place in the game, or anywhere else" for Haynesworth's behavior. However, [[ESPN]]{{'}}s [[Mark Schlereth]], a 12-year NFL veteran, felt that Haynesworth should have been suspended for the rest of the season. ESPN analyst [[Merril Hoge]] harshly criticized the officials for not ejecting Haynesworth immediately after the stomp.<ref>{{cite news|first=Merril |last=Hoge |title=Punishment for Haynesworth not severe enough |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2610631 |work=ESPN |date=October 2, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d1tN9QL?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2610631 |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Haynesworth's suspension is the longest for an in-game incident in modern NFL history.
The [[NFL Players Association]] initially planned to appeal the suspension, calling it too severe. However, Haynesworth said on October 3 that he would not appeal, after personally apologizing to Gurode in the same day. In a press conference on October 5, Haynesworth apologized to all who watched the game and said he had entered counseling to control his emotions. He also said that he would work with children in the Nashville area.
Fisher told Parcells after the game that the Titans would punish Haynesworth themselves if they felt the NFL's punishment was not harsh enough. On the same day as Haynesworth's press conference, Fisher told a national radio show that the Cowboys game may have been Haynesworth's last as a Titan. The team had the option of either deactivating him for the final seven games of the season or releasing him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Titans want Haynesworth to return bonus money |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D2615539 |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312258260FTDLGQFGNI?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D2615539 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |work=ESPN |date=October 7, 2006 }}</ref> Had the Titans released him, they had enough room under the salary cap to absorb the $5.5 million they would owe him for 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Haynesworth may face more punishment from Titans |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D2614453 |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312258363IQGXZMUAGB?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D2614453 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |work=ESPN |date=October 5, 2006 }}</ref>
Haynesworth was eligible to return on November 19 for the Titans' game against the [[2006 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]]. Even then, there was no guarantee that he would play. Haynesworth's agent, Chad Speck, told several media outlets that Haynesworth fully expected to return to practice on November 13, and he did indeed report that day. He played against the Eagles on November 19, and recorded one tackle.
====2007 season==== On September 9, 2007, in the season opener against the [[2007 Jacksonville Jaguars season|Jacksonville Jaguars]], Haynesworth was called for unnecessary roughness when he slammed running back [[Maurice Jones-Drew]] to the ground after a tackle.<ref>{{cite news |title=Titans' Haynesworth fined $5,000 for hard tackle |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2007-09-14-691404661_x.htm |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312258486FUNIYSZIIQ?url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2007-09-14-691404661_x.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 | work=USA Today | date=September 14, 2007 }}</ref> He was fined $5,000 by the NFL for this incident. Afterwards, when asked if he would be gentler during play, he commented, "I'm not going to be any gentler or whatever. Maybe I'll just help them up."
Haynesworth was elected to the [[Pro Bowl]] for the [[2008 Pro Bowl|first time]] for the [[2007 NFL season]]. During this season following the stomping incident, he ranked second on the team with six sacks in his 11 games played up to the selection, led or tied for the team-high in total tackles three times that season, and led or tied the team-high in quarterback pressures five times. At the point where the Pro Bowl selection was made, the [[2007 Tennessee Titans season|Titans]] had an 8-3 record in games in which Haynesworth started and were 0–3 in games in which he did not play.
Haynesworth said of his Pro Bowl selection, "It’s an awesome feeling. It’s kind of a load off my back because I didn’t want last year’s suspension to define my career. It was a difficult time in my life, but I was determined to keep working hard to get to this point and earn the respect of my teammates, coaches and fans." Haynesworth failed to sign with Tennessee due to the deadline of signing a franchise tagged player.<ref>{{cite news|first=Teresa M. |last=Walker |title=No deal between Titans, All Pro DT Haynesworth |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2008-07-15-3338044218_x.htm |work=USA Today |date=July 15, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d1Cdb1x?url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2008-07-15-3338044218_x.htm |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===Washington Redskins=== An [[unrestricted free agent]] in the 2009 off-season, Haynesworth signed a seven-year, $100 million contract with the [[Washington Redskins]] on the first day of free agency, February 27, 2009.<ref name="ClaytonESPN">{{cite news |first=John |last=Clayton |title=Albert Haynesworth, Washington Redskins agree on seven-year deal |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D3939011 |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312258562XCYKSEXXGS?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D3939011 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |work=ESPN |date=February 27, 2009 }}</ref> This was despite being offered more money<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2009/06/25/haynesworth-i-could-have-made-more-money-in-tampa-bay/|title=Haynesworth: I Could Have Made More Money In Tampa Bay|date=2009-06-25|work=ProFootballTalk|access-date=2018-03-21|language=en-US}}</ref> by the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]]. The deal was expected to pay Haynesworth $32 million in the first 13 months,<ref name="BattistaNYT" /> included $41 million guaranteed, and could have reached $115 million if all incentives were met.<ref name="ClaytonESPN" /> Tennessee’s final offer to Haynesworth reportedly amounted to a four-year package worth $34 million total, with about $20 million in guarantees.<ref>{{cite news |first=Terry |last=McCormick |title=How hard did the Titans work to re-sign Haynesworth? |url=http://nashvillecitypaper.com/content/sports/commentary-how-hard-did-titans-work-re-sign-haynesworth |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312258584LBEIQKXQKE?url=http://nashvillecitypaper.com/content/sports/commentary-how-hard-did-titans-work-re-sign-haynesworth |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |work=Nashville City Paper |date=April 9, 2009 }}</ref> Haynesworth reported on [[SIRIUS]] Blitz that the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] offered him a $120 million deal that could potentially increase by 20%. He says that he took a discount to play with the Redskins because of their large fan base and media outlet, something that he also did not have in Tennessee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2009/06/25/haynesworth-discusses-free-agency-details-vince-young/ |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312258771ZVOXPKSPUM?url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2009/06/25/haynesworth-discusses-free-agency-details-vince-young/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |title=FreezePage |publisher=FreezePage |accessdate=February 15, 2012}}</ref> In April 2009, the Titans asked the NFL to consider [[Tampering (Sports)|tampering]] charges against the Redskins, claiming that the Redskins contacted Haynesworth before the [[free agent|free agency]] period began on February 27.<ref>[http://www.freezepage.com/1312259074YXNDVKQNGD?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D4035877 Titans Ask NFL to Probe Signing] ESPN, April 2, 2009</ref>
From the beginning of his time with the Redskins, Haynesworth presented problems for the coaching staff. He refused to participate in off-season workouts, and arrived at camp in poor physical condition, unable to pass a basic fitness test.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/albert-haynesworth/albert-haynesworth-fails-to-co.html |work=The Washington Post |title=Albert Haynesworth fails to complete second part of conditioning test |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d58BBSA?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/albert-haynesworth/albert-haynesworth-fails-to-co.html |archivedate=2011-08-02 |df= }}</ref> He also made it clear that he did not like to play [[nose tackle]] in the team's 3–4 defensive scheme, having played in a 4–3 scheme in Tennessee.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/trainingcamp10/news/story?id=5429787 |title=Albert Haynesworth starts, but unable to finish, conditioning test |work=ESPN |date=August 3, 2010 }}</ref> After a 45–12 loss to the [[New York Giants]] on ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' in [[2009 NFL season|2009]], Haynesworth questioned the scheme of defensive coordinator [[Greg Blache]], and stated that he could not "survive another season in this system if it stays the way it is."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/25/AR2009122501780.html |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312259245UWHIMSQEEV?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/25/AR2009122501780.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |title=Haynesworth sounds off on Blache, defense after being sent home |newspaper=Washington Post |first=Jason |last=Reid |first2=Dan |last2=Steinberg |lastauthoramp=yes |date=December 26, 2009 }}</ref>
On December 7, 2010, it was announced that Haynesworth would spend the rest of the season on the restricted list. There had been conflicts throughout the 2010 preseason with Haynesworth and the coaching staff. After a dispute over his absence at a practice in which Haynesworth claimed to be ill, the team suspended him for "conduct detrimental to the club". Head coach [[Mike Shanahan]] said the suspension followed a refusal by Haynesworth to cooperate in a variety of ways and not only because of the practice absence.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/12/07/sportsline/main7126500.shtml |archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312259291ZTMEDIDAZS?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/12/07/sportsline/main7126500.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 2, 2011 |title=Redskins suspend Haynesworth 4 games without pay |date=December 7, 2010 }}</ref>
During the 2010 season, Haynesworth had a career-low 13 tackles and just 2.5 sacks in eight games, leading the [[NFL Network]] to name the signing of Haynesworth as the "worst free-agency move of last decade."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d81fe031a/article/easy-to-come-up-with-worst-freeagency-move-of-last-decade|title=Easy to come up with worst free-agency move of last decade|work=NFL.com|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> Many other NFL writers have gone further, calling Haynesworth the worst free agent bust in NFL history.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/fanfuel/2012/03/28/nfl_free_agent_busts/ |title=Fan Fuel: Top 10 NFL free agent busts |work=SportsNet |date=March 28, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1073638-50-biggest-free-agent-signing-busts-in-nfl-history/page/52|title=NFL|author=Dan Van Wie|work=Bleacher Report|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> Haynesworth created some controversy in March 2015 when he likened [[Ndamukong Suh]]'s six-year, $114 million contract to his previous contract with the Redskins.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Albert Haynesworth offers advice to Ndamukong Suh|url = http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000476581/article/albert-haynesworth-offers-advice-to-ndamukong-suh|website = NFL.com|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
===New England Patriots=== Haynesworth was traded to the [[New England Patriots]] on July 28, 2011, for a fifth-round draft pick in the [[2013 NFL Draft]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Farrar|first=Doug|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/blog/shutdown_corner/post/Patriots-trade-for-Haynesworth-Redskins-left-to?urn%3Dnfl-wp4049|archive-url=http://www.freezepage.com/1312259398PQGTSWAQVR?url=http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/blog/shutdown_corner/post/Patriots-trade-for-Haynesworth-Redskins-left-to?urn%3Dnfl-wp4049|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 2, 2011|title=Patriots trade for Haynesworth; Redskins left to sell cut-rate jerseys|work=Shutdown Corner: A Yahoo! Sports Blog|accessdate=August 2, 2011}}</ref> He lasted less than four months with the Patriots, and on November 8, 2011, Haynesworth was placed on waivers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Reiss |first=Mike |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/boston/new-england-patriots/post/_/id/4708671/albert-haynesworth-analysis |title=Albert Haynesworth analysis – New England Patriots Blog – ESPN Boston |publisher=ESPN |accessdate=February 15, 2012}}</ref> His placement on waivers came days after he got into a confrontation with assistant [[Pepper Johnson]] on the sidelines.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Scott|title=The Haynesworth Experiment is Over|url=http://bleacherbumsports.net/2011/11/08/the-haynesworth-experiment-is-over/|work=Bleacher Bum Sports|accessdate=November 8, 2011}}</ref>
===Tampa Bay Buccaneers=== Two days after being released by the Patriots, Haynesworth was claimed off waivers by the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]]. On February 15, 2012, he was released by the team.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/TBBuccaneers/statuses/169837201511825408|title=Twitter|work=twitter.com|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref>
===NFL statistics=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Team !! GP !! COMB !! Total !! AST !! Sack !! FF !! FR !! FR yds !! INT !! IR yds !! AVG IR !! LNG IR !! TD !! ==Legal issues== Arrest warrants were issued against Haynesworth in two [[Tennessee]] counties in May 2006 stemming from a traffic incident on [[Interstate 40]]. Both sets of charges were dropped in June 2006. The judge in the [[Putnam County, Tennessee|Putnam County]] case tossed the charges on the grounds that the alleged offense happened out of their jurisdiction. In [[Smith County, Tennessee|Smith County]], the district attorney dismissed the charges. In March 2009, Haynesworth was indicted on two [[misdemeanor]] traffic charges stemming from a December 2008 car accident in Tennessee.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D3974042 |archive-url= http://www.freezepage.com/1312259439DCNZUBYRBU?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id%3D3974042 |dead-url= yes |archive-date= August 2, 2011 |title= Haynesworth Indicted on Traffic Charges |publisher=ESPN | date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=August 2, 2011 }}</ref> In an accident on [[Interstate 65]], Corey Edmonson was partially paralyzed after colliding with Haynesworth's car. Haynesworth was driving his Ferrari at speeds in excess of 100 mph when he struck Edmonson's vehicle, which struck a concrete barrier.<ref name="bleacher">{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/397200-albert-haynesworths-lawsuit-is-another-headache-for-washington-redskins |title=Albert Haynesworth's Lawsuit Is Another Headache for Washington Redskins |publisher=Bleacher Report |date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d4KMONy?url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/397200-albert-haynesworths-lawsuit-is-another-headache-for-washington-redskins |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
On June 22, 2010, it was reported that Clayton Bank & Trust was suing the NFL lineman, alleging that Haynesworth had failed to make payments on a loan in the amount of more than $2.38 million. The suit was filed in the Knox County Chancery Court on June 18, 2010. According to papers, Haynesworth entered a commercial [[loan agreement]] for the original principal amount of $2,381,688.58 on June 27, 2009. On February 27, 2009, the two parties entered into an Extension Agreement with an effective date of February 27, 2010, according to the suit. The attorney for Clayton Bank & Trust, Hugh B. Ward, Jr., was seeking a little over $2.4 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/albert-haynesworth/albert-haynesworth-sued-by-ten.html |work=The Washington Post |title=Albert Haynesworth sued by Tennessee bank |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d4ZQpaA?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/albert-haynesworth/albert-haynesworth-sued-by-ten.html |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In 2010, Silvia Mena, a stripper from [[New York City|New York]], claimed in a $10 million lawsuit that Haynesworth impregnated her and left her with no financial assistance.<ref name="bleacher" />
In 2011, Haynesworth allegedly threw a punch to the nose of Joel Velazques, 38, of [[Leesburg, Virginia]] during a traffic altercation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=6090069 |title=Albert Haynesworth accused in Virginia |date=February 4, 2011 |accessdate=June 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d4bDxGi?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=6090069 |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In January 2015, Haynesworth plead guilty for reckless boating charges.
==In popular culture== In a response to Haynesworth’s failure to pass the Redskins' conditioning test in July 2010,<ref name="conditioning">{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/albert-haynesworth/albert-haynesworth-fails-to-co.html |title=Albert Haynesworth fails to complete second part of conditioning test |work=Washington Post |date=July 29, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d58BBSA?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/redskinsinsider/albert-haynesworth/albert-haynesworth-fails-to-co.html |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name="era">{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dcsportsbog/2010/12/five_worst_moments_of_the_hayn.html |title=Five worst moments of the Haynesworth era |work=Washington Post |date=December 7, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d5Il3eb?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dcsportsbog/2010/12/five_worst_moments_of_the_hayn.html |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> the August 27, 2010 edition of satire news organization ''[[The Onion]]'' ran the headline (with an accompanying photo), "Report: Albert Haynesworth Just A Mound Of Ice Cream And Hot Dogs."<ref name="onion">{{cite web |url=http://www.onionsportsnetwork.com/articles/report-albert-haynesworth-just-a-mound-of-ice-crea,17976/ |title=Report: Albert Haynesworth Just A Mound Of Ice Cream And Hot Dogs |publisher=The Onion |date=August 27, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60d5PpJWB?url=http://www.onionsportsnetwork.com/articles/report-albert-haynesworth-just-a-mound-of-ice-crea,17976/ |archivedate=2011-08-02 |df= }}</ref>
